title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie Alurray's marriage was a great affair, avery great affair, both for him and Blinkbonny.. forit was a " house-heating" and a " home-coming'combined; and, despite Airs. Eankine's strongly-expressed desire to have everything as quiet as possible,the arrangements were left to young Benjie Cranstoun,Beck Eiddell, and George Lockhart, with generalinstructions " to see that everything was mensefu' an'wisehke, an' to hae a royal supper in the ' Black Bull.' "

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The examinations were great occasions, especiallythe August one, when the prizes and the vacationswere given; the spring examination was almostprivate, being conducted by the Presbytery ofBlinkbonny, and had special reference to religiousteaching. But the August examination was the eventof the year.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: As we reached the Broomhill road we metMrs. Stewart of Greenknowe, her daughter Mary, andLily Easton, the youngest daughter of the farmer ofBlinkbonny Mains—one of the largest farms in theparish. The farmhouse was an old mansion-house,and was situated about two miles to the north-east ofthe village.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Saturday at Blinkbonny school was a half holiday,but an exacting review of the week's work made theforenoon a busy one. The higher classes repeatedtheir week's tasks to the master or the helper;thereafter, those who had gone through these well

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Tlie day of election was a busy one hi Larkton,the poUing station for Blinkbonny. Alatthew Eiddellwas a busy man until about two o'clock, but the airof the committee room had been too strong for him;for thereafter he dozed in a corner, and kept inquiring,as the reports from the various districts came in, " Is theyoung man Absalom yet alive ?" until he was assistedinto a carriage and quietly conveyed to Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: George Alarr,who was now master of works on Blinkbonny estate,and in a fair way to become the " factor," had gonein to see the Scott Monument, and to study itsbeautiful proportions and details. He met SimonaccidentaUy, and, after a short chat about Blinkbonny folks, George asked him how he was engaged.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The tailor was sewing away after the marriage andthe feast as usual in his cross-legged fashion beforefour o'clock in the afternoon. Tibbie employed herselfin carrying several " rakes " of water, to be ready fora " scouring " on the following day; and, when theidlers gathered round the door at night, expecting tosee the minister arrive, they saw that Tibbie had twostoups full of water standing suspiciously near thewindow, and, fearing that she might damp their ardourwith these (not a pleasant prospect on a cold Octoberevening), the mob melted away; and it became abyword in Blinkbonny, " as quiet as Strachan Gemmell's marriage wi' Tibbie Murray;" for her maidenname had been the same as that of her first husband,and she continued to be " Tibbie Murray."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Tlie day of election was a busy one hi Larkton,the poUing station for Blinkbonny. Alatthew Eiddellwas a busy man until about two o'clock, but the airof the committee room had been too strong for him;for thereafter he dozed in a corner, and kept inquiring,as the reports from the various districts came in, " Is theyoung man Absalom yet alive ?" until he was assistedinto a carriage and quietly conveyed to Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " Here's your bundle, Annie; it's aye tapmost,"said Mrs. Dunbar, taking out a round-shaped bundletied in a blue cotton handkerchief, with two crumpledpaper labels roughly stitched on it, that had done servicefor several journeys. The one ran, " Adam Eankine,Gibbiesbrae, Blinkbonny;" the other, "William Eankine,Mrs. Dinwoodie's, Number 19 Patterraw, Edinburgh ;"and both labels bore " to be called for."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Within a month she wascomfortably settled in Blinkbonny, and so were thetwo nice milk cows that kind friends had provided. At the bottom of the garden she found stances erectedfor her beehives, and a pig-house ready; so that aUher Uve stock were soon as much at home inBlinkbonny as they had been at Gibbiesbrae.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Within a week Mrs. Eankine was told that asmall holding in the Laigh Eoad of Blinkbonny, witha house, a smaU garden, a park, and a byre for threecows, was taken for her. Within a month she wascomfortably settled in Blinkbonny, and so were thetwo nice milk cows that kind friends had provided. At the bottom of the garden she found stances erectedfor her beehives, and a pig-house ready; so that aUher Uve stock were soon as much at home inBlinkbonny as they had been at Gibbiesbrae.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: the one had been known to see the other Jwme andback again to the " Black Bull Inn," their " howff" atBlinkbonny, regardless of the extra thirty miles atfurious speed which they took out of their mettleponies, for so their undersized roadsters were called.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: I gotmy gas plans, and Kennedy, Strachan Gemmell,and I walked to the front street of the village together. Kennedy's head seemed so confused by " the awfu'dearness o' claith the noo," and the coming destructionof Blinkbonny by gas, that he said little. Strachan'sparcel had not come, and he consoled himself bysaying, " 'Deed, I hardly expected it," which was verylikely, for the carrier's, on Thursday, was a greatattraction for him.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The quarters of Jamie Dunbar, the carrier, adjoinedBenjie Cranstoun's cooperage, or, to use the Scotchexpression, " marched wi' the capper's;" and therewas a weekly gathering of folks from the village andfrom the surrounding country at the carrier's onThursday evenings, for he did all the small carryingtrade of the district, and many came to get theirexpected parcels; while not a few came to hear thelatest news, as Jamie Dunbar was the most regularchannel of communication within their reach, betweenthe great world and Uttle Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: npiIE adjourned discussion on the subject of lighting-^ by gas in general, and of the propriety andsafety of its being introduced into Blinkbonny inparticular, came off earlier than some of us expecte—for it occurred at the carrier's quarterson the Thursday night immediately following themeeting at George Lockhart's described in the lastchapter.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Blinkbonny, not bits out of old newspapers read morethan fifty years ago in Blinkbonny; and, although thequotations are genuine, I fear they will be thoughtexcessive and tedious. I will therefore, in nextchapter, stay more "amongst my own people," orrather, relate their discussion of a subject that camenearer home to them than either the Coronation or theEeform Bill; namely, the threatened introduction oflighting by gas into the village.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John

I will therefore, in nextchapter, stay more "amongst my own people," orrather, relate their discussion of a subject that camenearer home to them than either the Coronation or theEeform Bill; namely, the threatened introduction oflighting by gas into the village.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: A DISSOLUTION of Parhament took place in July1837, shortly after the accession of QueenVictoria to the throne of Great Britain, and thegeneral election which foUowed in the latter part ofthat year, created considerable excitement in andaround Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: It was heartdy taken up, and as heartily carriedout. Within a week Mrs. Eankine was told that asmall holding in the Laigh Eoad of Blinkbonny, witha house, a smaU garden, a park, and a byre for threecows, was taken for her. Within a month she wascomfortably settled in Blinkbonny, and so were thetwo nice milk cows that kind friends had provided.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: There was nothing for it but that Jamiemust humour the boy, and convoy Annie so far on theroad. They had reached the Fillies' Bridge, where theysat down to rest by the burn-side, and tried to induceStrachan to return to Blinkbonny. He -would haveAnnie to go back with him, and kept saying, " Willyou no' come an' bide wi' Jamie, an' be my Annieand his ?" It was the longest sentence he had everuttered, and Jamie and Annie between them followedit up,—she by promising Strachan to do so, andJamie by saying "He hopit she wad keep her word."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: James was a very nice lad, very correct andnervously polite,—almost painfully so, for he was asprecise at seventeen as his aunt was at , and itsat badly on such young shoulders. This may haveoriginated the diminutive name " Jimsie," by which hewas best known in Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: off, and the house had no mistress excepting PeggyEitchie, my housekeeper, general servant, and animportant factor in domestic Blinkbonny. Mrs. Barrie's" BeU" helped Peggy on this occasion, but she did notquite like some of Bell's remarks about" wasterfu'ness "and " thowlessness," possibly because they were onlytoo true.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Theletter also contained references to his hoping to bepresent at Alaggie's marriage, with a sprig of forgetme-not in his coat. He also sent kind regardsto all his Blinkbonny friends, not forgetting the goodsulks at Greenknowe.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie himself worked like a slave allday, only occasionally looking out at the window, orstepping into the stackyard to see how " wee Strachan "was getting on. The child was happy, happy ; thismade all about him happy too, and the visit wasoften referred to in the tailor's kitchen at Blinkbonny, for the poor child was every now and againimitating, or recalling in his wandering way, thesights and sounds of his first holiday at Gibbiesbrae.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie resolved that, on the next King's Birthday,which was a regular holiday in Blinkbonny, he would" gie Mrs. Eankine a day's sewing ;" and when he toldhor this, she asked him to bring " wee Strachan " withhim. This went closer to Jamie's heart than almostanything else could have done, and the twenty-firstday of August was eagerly looked forward to.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie heard him plunge into the " deep pool," and itcomforted him to think that there was " somebody elsenear him if onything happened." He heard besidesthe blowing of a powerful swimmer, and concludedthat it would be Willie Fairbairn, the best swimmerin Blinkbonny. He was anxiously waiting to seeWillie turn the rock, when, to Jamie's indescribablehorror, the face of the big, lusty negro, with its whiterolling eyes, thick red lips, and gleaming teeth, camequickly towards him.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Lily and the doctor made more of Eobert than theminister or his father had done. As Mr. Morrisonreturned to Blinkbonny in the evening, he met NicolFairbairn, who at once started the subject of " thisscandalous horse-racing business 0' young Easton's." Mr. Morrison began by telling him, that it was againsthis father's will and knowledge that the event hadtaken place, which drew from Nicol, " He must be astubborn and rebellious son; he would have beenstoned to death under the old economy."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Many ofhis comrades called for Eobert; most of them had alsoto see Malcolm. One of the " regulars," a sergeant ina cavalry regiment, was recruiting in Blinkbonny, andsome friends brought him to see the charger. BabbieGaw was working in the farmyard, near the court inwhich " Malcolm Canmore " was.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: By this time we had reached the village, and aswe parted Andrew's last words were, "Noo, sit doonthis very nicht, and write ' More Bits from Blinkbonny,'an' begin wi' the schules."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Lest my readers may think that I am overpraising Mr. M'Nab, I have only quoted the opinionsof others, and I insert here what I have oftenrepeated in his hearing, that I never heard himcome up to his second Sabbath's work at Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: After his third session at college, he was employedas a town missionary in Edinburgh. George Alarr,who was now master of works on Blinkbonny estate,and in a fair way to become the " factor," had gonein to see the Scott Monument, and to study itsbeautiful proportions and details. He met SimonaccidentaUy, and, after a short chat about Blinkbonny folks, George asked him how he was engaged.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: "TI7HEN Mr. M'Nab went next day to inquire abouthis flower-pot and its valuable contents, hewas accosted, almost immediately on entering theapproach to Greenknowe, by Matthew Eiddell, thejobbing gardener of the village, upon whose broadback lay the responsibilities of the outside work ofmany of the villas of Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " Sit down, Mr. M'Nab, please," said Maggie. " MaryStewart has the best-balanced heart in Blinkbonny;she must have been out on one of her morning errandsof mercy, in what we women folks call 'householdcostume'" (for a something of the kind had fallen outbetween John M'Lauchlan and herself, that did her

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: What do I care for Mary Stewart ? I amas good as she any day. I wish I had never seenBlinkbonny ;" and much more in the same strain.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: When I first knew him he was at Blinkbonny toll. The tollman and his wife were old and the house lonely, and Bob was too terrific for any burglar.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Back hecame to the forget-me-nots again, and his face gotredder than ever, as he asked a sprig to preserve as acuriosity (?), and, if not presuming too much, a plantto take home with him. John meant a week hence,when he left Blinkbonny; Maryr—generous, gentleMary—thought he meant now, went for a flower-pot,scooped out a good big bunch with her hollow trowel,put it into the flower-pot, and said she would sendthe servant with it to Mr. Martin's to-morrow.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Miss Stewart's dress was of the same material, forMiss Whale, of Earlston gingham notoriety, visitedBlinkbonny periodically, and the uniform excellenceof her wares, combined with the good taste displayedin their design and colouring, were duly appreciatedby all thrifty housewives. The other parts ofMiss Stewart's dress were similar to Miss Easton's,excepting that there were no " forget-me-nots " in herhat.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Accordingly, he got Simon Lockhart to write amost elaborate letter to his colonial relative, thankinghim for his remittance, and for his good advice, andstating that he would be obliged to him if he wouldallow him to " set up " a cloth-shop in Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie Murray, better known around Blinkbonny as" Big Murray," was a dull soft boy with a dumplinglooking face. His mother, Tibbie Murray, had had aneventful and sad life.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: T)EFOBE my brother's death and my father's illnessbrought me back to Blinkbonny, I had, as alreadystated by Mr. Andrew Taylor in the opening chapter,been prosecuting my studies for the Christian ministryat the University of Edinburgh. John M'Nab and Ilodged in the same house, and, as he was nearlythrough the Divinity Hall, he was of great help to mein my studies.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The " Carters' Play," so graphically depicted by MissJ. L. Watson in her delightful volume, Bound theGrange Form, is an equally vivid picture of the" Carters' Play" at Blinkbonny. It was the great" ploy" of the year, with its mounted procession,streaming flags, " buskit" horses glancing with ribbonsand looking-glasses; its clattering races of thicklegged cart-horses along the macadamized road,—forone of the laws, to secure that only cart-horses shouldrun, was thus announced by Wee Peelie, the clerk ofthe course, " That nae horse was allooed to rin that hadony bluid in't;" its rough and round dinner, consisting of enormous pies or lamb legs, cooked at thebaker's, where they were called for after the raceswere over, and carried off and consumed in privatehouses; the noisy evening meeting, at which eventhe very liberal law that no more than six shouldspeak at once was disregarded ; the " roupin' o' theflags," and the absurd prices paid for the honour of

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: At one fair, " Wombwell's Menagerie" was thegreat attraction. The elephant was occasionally ledtlirough the street, and this created the greatestsensation of my young days in Blinkbonny. Theshows, even the hobby-horses, were deserted.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " AVhen wine is in,wit is out." Jamie Murray had called that day, buthad gone back to Blinkbonny three hours ago. Annie was full of home news, and had begun to tellthem to AVillie, when he said:

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: When I first knew him he was at Blinkbonny toll. The tollman and his wife were old and the house lonely, and Bob was too terrific for any burglar.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: AVhen the day of Dr. Forrest's leaving Blinkbonnyarrived, his last call was at The Mains. Mrs. Eastonwas greatly affected, and showed it.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: rpilE severe winter of 1837-38 caused a good dealof distress among the poor folks in Blinkbonny,and, at a meeting of charitable ladies, it was resolvedto establish a " Soup-kitchen," where at least one plainbut substantial meal could be had daily by the mostnecessitous. Airs.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The most persistent of these topers of fifty yearsago were Gideon Elliot o' the Craigs, and SamuelDickie o' Bentyhaugh. Luckily their farms lay ondifferent sides of Blinkbonny, Craigie's being fifteenmiles to the south-west, and Benty's twelve milesto the north-east. Even once a week was too oftenfor them to meet, for in the madness of their cups

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Blinkbonny market had its " Tam o' Shanters," andthere were too many " Souter Johnnies," ready to sit

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: AVhen the Eev. John M'Nab's marriage came off,Lily Easton was one of the bridesmaids, and shesweetly7 expressed the feelings of many hundreds inBlinkbonny towards Aliss Stewart, in the song whichshe sang, "Wha's at the Window," especially in theselines:—

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: and by repute a genius and a prominent radical; butan accident to his knee made him unfit to work tlie" treddles" of his loom, and he started a school for—so the written " prospectus " ran that was stuckup in a few shop windows in Blinkbonny—" teachingthe elementary branches of education at very moderatewages."

title: Rab and his friends and other dogs and men,
author: Brown, John
snippet: When I first knew him he was at Blinkbonny toll. The tollman and his wife were old and the house lonely, and Bob was too terrific for any burglar.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Strachan repeated at his own fireside the tobaccopipe gas-making experiment successfully, to theedification and wonder of a great many of the scepticsin Blinkbonny, and he began to " believe in gas" soonerthan some of the middle-class folks in the village did;for travelling was rare, expensive, and dangerous inthose days. Many of the promoters had never seengas used, and were very doubtful about having anything to do with it.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: burning or at all scorching the skin. The process issometimes called " singin'," and many a Sundaydinner in Blinkbonny consisted of a " singit" sheep'shead and trotters. Glorious broth it made, dottedwith " blue pat peas," turbid with barley brae, andaccompanied by a bit of a pease bannock; a snuff o'the " singe " in it was not objectionable, and the headand trotters went " far," in housekeeping phrase,backed up as they were with turnips, carrots, androasted potatoes.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: So did most of the dogs about Blinkbonny, for BigMurray was seldom without some running after him;and possibly Moffat, the butcher's dog, and he hadbeen old friends before they became fellow-servants.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: A little black-eyed Italian boy, after playing throughpart of Blinkbonny on an instrument which we boyscalled a " French fiddle," had sat down on the pavement at Luckie Baxter's window, in the brightglare of the sun. The sky that day was cloudless,quite an Italian sky, and possibly the wee laddie washaving a waking dream of home.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: lay sound asleep in the box-bed, but Big Murray haddrunk in the doleful predictions, and, being accustomedto look up to Strachan as his father and guide, he gotno comfort from his mother's sensible coolness on thesubject. His mind was a chamber of horrors, inwhich explosions were scattering Blinkbonny and itsinhabitants over the Strath.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The setting sun was now beginning to sink behindDunsarg, the highest hill in the district, which layabout six miles distant from Blinkbonny, putting tbewestern and northern sides of the strath into darkshadow, but making the southern and eastern sideslook more lovely by the contrast.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: ~\ TY old friend and schoolfellow, Andrew Taylor,and I were taking a leisurely stroll, on alovely evening in the month of June 1884. Wewere going to " Nancie's Knowe," a little hillock,easy of ascent, that rose among the braes at theback of Blinkbonny. Its sides sloped gently, andwere covered with a soft grassy sward, the delightof the children of the village ; while on its summitthere were some fine old Scotch firs, on which thesunlight streamed, making their red trunks andstems seem all the brighter from the dark greenof their thick covering of foliage.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "And, by my troth," continued the sister, "I think the guidwife o'Middlebie, wha bade us change Cauldshouthers to Blinkbonny, was a weeenvious, and deserved a catechising for her pains."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: fury, several years before. AVillie Eankine was instructed to procure a first-class " cutter" for Jamie'sextending business, and this, coupled with his wife'stact, made him prosper so much, that even Kennedy,the opposition tailor, found it more profitable to buyfrom him than from Draper Eenwick, who was almostthe only man in Blinkbonny that grudged Jamie hissuccess. There was, moreover, no happier home inthe parish than Air.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Nearly a year elapsed before any reply was received. When this came, it not only sanctioned Jamie's proposal, but it contained something which enabled himto stock the shop comfortably, as well as to providehimself with a blue coat and yeUow buttons, a beaverhat, a buff waistcoat, and suitable continuations;indeed, he became the dandy tailor of Blinkbonny. It also put it in his power to be kind to all theGemmells, and this pleased him quite as much asanything else could have done.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: a handsome young woman, and AVillie paid her moreattention than the mere fact of them both beingBlinkbonny folks seemed to warrant.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The long-continued and intense frost in the winterof 1837-38 had a cooling effect, especially amongstcurlers, on the hot blood and bitterness of feelingcaused by the election. This game they played on aloch within Sir John Al'Lelland's policy, but for thefirst two days of the "ice," the Blinkbonny clubmustered badly. Sir John was a keen curler, and to

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Victory having declared itself on the popular side,no such ruffianism was displayed as there had been in1833, when the Tories gained the day. The onlywindows broken in Blinkbonny were those of AllanCrawford ; and some hard-hearted people on bothsides said "he was cheap o't." He seemed ashamedof himself; at aU events, he made no claim on thecounty for the damage he had sustained, but quietlyreplaced the glass, saying to himself, " I hope it'llbe a lang, lang time afore there's anither o' thaeabom'nable elections."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: A ten - pounds proprietorship or a fifty - poundsoccupancy were the qualifications which then entitleda person to have a vote; but some of the tradesmen inBlinkbonny, who were voters, thought the franchiseanything but a privilege—notably Allan Crawford, thehouse painter. He had no defined political opinions, andwas very much afraid of offending any of his customers.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Lord Dunsarg was the leading Whig in the district;Sir John M'Lelland, the lord of the manor of Blinkbonny, was a strong Tory; and each exerted hispowerful influence on behalf of the candidate hefavoured, whom I will call Sir Francis Davidson onthe Tory side, and Sir George Carse on the Whig.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: M'Nab'sannoyance, for he had resolved to be Aliss Stewart'ssquire that day, and Dr. Forrest had appointedhimself to play the same part to Lily Easton. Tlieyoung doctor, however, was called to a case of medicalurgency fully ten miles distant, and the picnicparty was back in Blinkbonny before his return. Jimsie religiously carried out his aunt's instructions,and was painfully attentive to Miss Stewart duringthe ascent of the hill.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Stewart and Miss Agnes, for, when MissStewart came to deliver the message, all in thedrawing-room had laughed so heartily as to havegood cause to remember him. Dr. Forrest saw tothat, for he was ever and anon repeating Jimsie'spantomime and question, " Will these—do ?" Andwhen Lily Easton told her brothers at home, theyvery improperly retold it in Scotch, and questions orreferences as to suitabdity of dress were, and stillare, put by some of the Blinkbonny folks in twowords, " Jimsie Park."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Mr. Martin asked me to look in for an hourthis evening to meet you." Then, lifting his hat, hesaid, " Good-night, Miss Stewart; now, Mr. M'Nab ;"and the young minister and the young doctor proceeded to Blinkbonny together, but, strange as it mayseem, John had again forgotten to inquire about, oreven to refer to, his pot of forget-me-not.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The only barber of which Blinkbonny was possessedwas George Lockhart, and Maggie had herself goneto " tryst" him to come to the house after tea;she had also told him that it was the youngminister who had preached on Sabbath that required hishair-cutting services, and that it was more " trimming "than cutting that was needed. She succeeded so wellin impressing George with the necessity' of doing hisbest, that he appeared in his Sunday clothes, with anew brush and comb, a clean overall cloth andtowel, and thoroughly organized for his work, which wasdone carefully and well, to the decided improvementof Mr. M'Nali's personal appearance.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " This place is well named Blinkbonny," said John ;" I congratulate you on your home, although I regretthat my hopes of seeing you appear as the Bev. BobertMartin will not now be realized.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The great fair of the year was held in September,and it was a busy day in Blinkbonny. Horses, cattle,and sheep covered the Annie Green.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: I am notsure whether it has hitherto appeared in print; butI insert it as a bona fide specimen of the earlystyle of a writer who, under many " aliases," has asmall corner in modern bookshelves. Moreover, itsglimpses of country life, as exhibited at a hiring fairmore than twenty years ago, and its account of anexpedient adopted to counteract the evils which I havebeen depicting, are those of an eye-witness ; and to me,its perusal recalls vividly the hiring fairs of Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Fairs were very common in Blinkbonny,—hiringfairs, plant fairs, " horses and cattle," " wool andshearers," " ewes and lambs," etc.,—and great, for the

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Even when they were aroused, it took them whatthe impatient travellers outside called " a most unconscionable time " to gather their brains, and pull onhastily such garments as the weather suggested—slipshodly many of these were pulled on. Oftendid Baillie, the keeper of the " High Toll" of Blinkbonny, use his wife's undergarments on such occasions,and sometimes she used his.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: sTlHE weekly market held in Blinkbonny in myyoung days was largely attended by farmersand artisans from the surrounding district, as well asby merchants, and, indeed, persons of all sorts. Themarket-place proper was enclosed within high walls,and, with the exception of a light projecting shed-roofcarried round part of the sides and the entrance end,it was open to the sky, and paved with rough burncauseway.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Old Mr. Taylor said " He would take shares becausehe could trust to the reports of those who had seen itand tried it; but for all that, it was a leap in thedark, and the gaswork should be as far away fromthe place as possible; and particular care would needto be taken not to let any light get near the ' gasholder,' or Blinkbonny would be blawn over the faceo' a' the country like snawflakes in a storm."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Draper Eenwick wasan ill-liked man, and deservedly so. The rebuff thathe had got greatly increased the number of coppersthat the wee strolling musician gathered in Blinkbonny that day; and when he started for Larkton, thecounty town of the district, a good many boys convoyed him to the Filhesbridge, and, after they hadparted with him, they cheered him, and followed himwith their eyes till he was lost to sight. Big Murraymounted on the parapet of the bridge to try to getanother look, but the boy was " off and away."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: that ran loose about Blinkbonny. He had a knackof whistling on his fingers in a shrill, yet strangelymodulated tone, that drew them about him.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " Weel, he'll hae seen gas mony atime, for I think he's been every place, an' seen everything. If ye hae a chance o' speakin' to him withoutbein' ill-bred or forritsome, ask him if he thinks thatit's safe to put gas-pipes into the streets o' Blinkbonny. There's ae thing, it'll never come into ma house, butye can ask him about takin't into houses tae."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: OTEACHAN GEMMELL, on his return home, lostno time in communicating to Tibbie, with addedhorrors out of his own terror-stricken head, the fearfuldestruction that gas was bringing on Britain generally,and was likely to bring before long on Blinkbonny. While he was repeating what George Marr and othershad said about it, Tibbie looked at him with anamused, inquiring glance, for the dismal tale did noteven excite, much less frighten her.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: To say that a sharp discussion followed is to givebut a faint idea of the Babel, and I will not attemptto reproduce it. It was quickly cut short by GeorgeLockhart saying: " Let Mr. Eobert read about the illuminations, and the other contents of the newspapers,and do not interrupt him, for it's not the opinions ofBlinkbonny people we wish, but the real, absolute newsprinted in the papers. Please begin with the openingleading article, and read on, Mr. Eobert, if you please."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: forefathers, and learn and romp as they did; andmany sleep with kindred dust. May the sunnymemories of " Auld Langsyne" warm the hearts ofthose survivors who read these long-past bits from thoannals of the schools of Blinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Where are now the merry boys and sprightlygirls that were scholars at Blinkbonny in my youngdays, and how have they sped ? Some have heldhigh positions in the army and navy, and have fallenin their country's cause ; some have risen to eminenceat home, and still adorn the pulpit, the bench, thebar, and the council board. Many have had a distinguished career in foreign lands, and still survive toguide the councils and shape the destinies of thelargest dependencies of Britain.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Mr. Torrancewas the name of the teacher in those days. Mr.Sinclair was tlie " helper,"— for pupil teachers or" certificated assistants" were unknown in Blinkbonny—and sadly were his faculties of mind and bodytaxed to make " Big Murray " learn, or even look atanything, excepting straight and always at himself. Mr. Sinclair for two or three weeks spent some timewith Jamie after the other scholars had gone, andpartly succeeded in getting him to take some interestin his lessons ; and on one occasion he asked AVillie

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The chat I had had with Mr. Taylor, and his graphicdescription of scenes long since huddled up in oddcorners of my memory, set me a-scribbling; but Ifear that, to use his simile, I will not only have todecipher long-forgotten sheets of my cast-off blottingpaper, but to draw from otber, and perhaps as confusing sources, in these " More Bits from Blinkbonny,"which, at his request, I shall begin with some referencesto " Big Murray."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Mr. Taylor went over a long list of names andevents interwoven with our early days at Blinkbonny ; and we had a rambling chat, which recalledincidents that had long lain dormant in our memories.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: " That book o' yours, Bobert," said Andrew, " is,as I told you before, ' no bad, considerin';' but thereare lots of more ' Bits from Blinkbonny ' that you mustput together. There's, for instance, the schule, orrather the schules; for George Lockhart's bit'sideschule was a queer place, and George himself was

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: When we had reached the top, and the snuglittle place lay at our feet, with its picturesque surroundings of hill and valley, river and woodland,We felt that the only suitable names for the strathand the village were precisely those they bore—-Strathbonny and Blinkbonny. And, familiar as wewere with every nook and corner of the landscape,we " turned and gazed, and turned again;" for theevening was a beautiful one.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 04
author: Various
snippet: "And, by my troth," continued the sister, "I think the guidwife o'Middlebie, wha bade us change Cauldshouthers to Blinkbonny, was a weeenvious, and deserved a catechising for her pains."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Syne down by Blinkbonny tbe burnie rins,Wi' its glintin', glimmerin' sheen ;

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: As it was inthe days o' Noah, so it is in our time: ' The earth isfilled with violence through them'; it's a sinfultempting of Providence. Some day we'll have aregular Vesuvius in Blinkbonny, and be a' blawn tobits. It's a black burnin' shame! The inventors ofsuch evil things would have been stoned to deathunder the Jewish economy."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: IV/TE. TOBBANCE, the parish schoolmaster ofBlinkbonny, was a well-read, scholarly man.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: We canna bide in Blinkbonny to be blawn to bits. But she's gaun to be washin' the morn at Mr.Spowart the gauger's, an' he's been in a heap o' pantso' the world, an' I'll tell her to ask him, for he's sureto ken a' about it, an' to hae seen 't."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: IITE. EASTON, the farmer of Blinkbonny Mains,was a hard-working, industrious man. In his

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The result was that a Gas Company was formed,and, in course of time, a gaswork was erected inBlinkbonny.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: who wished to introduce them to the beauties ofBlinkbonny.
